Though the body of the woman in the video was thinner and whiter than hers, it was undeniably her face. She couldn‚Äôt stop crying. How could it look so realistic? And what could she do about it?\nAs the capabilities of artificial intelligence rapidly increase, so do the ways people are targeted by it.¬†According to¬†Psychology Today, ‚Äú[a 2019] study reports that 96% of deepfake victims are sexualized, and nearly all of them are women.‚Äù Lauren had found herself, as many others have, the victim of deepfake porn ‚Äì an¬†increasingly popular subset of pornography where a person‚Äôs face is superimposed onto another person‚Äôs body and then seen engaging in sexual activity. The creators of deepfake porn don‚Äôt have to be computer geniuses ‚Äì the videos¬†can be created with relatively simple¬†face swapping¬†apps available on most phones. Newer, more advanced AI tech makes the phenomenon even more likely to proliferate.\nLauren, whose name has been changed for privacy concerns, was the subject of deepfake porn after Dan*, a man she met at the local gym asked her out on a date. When she told him she wasn‚Äôt interested, she didn‚Äôt think much of it but Lauren says the next time she saw Dan at the gym, the situation escalated. ‚ÄúHe became aggressive and frustrated, saying I should just give him a chance,‚Äù Lauren said. I should have told the gym management but I was embarrassed and just wanted to get out of there.‚Äù When Lauren returned to the gym again, she said a man followed her toward the locker rooms and said he needed to speak to her. ‚ÄúHe told me Dan was showing people a video of us having sex,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt believe him at first because I‚Äôd never had sex with Dan so it didn‚Äôt seem possible.‚Äù\nBut thanks to the rise in deepfake and face swap technology, it was possible. Dan had created a video that appeared to show him and Lauren having sex and was showing the men at the gym, Lauren said. A few days later, Dan posted the video on his Instagram story, using Lauren‚Äôs first and last name and bragging that he would turn the fake video into a reality. After reporting Dan to the management of the gym, Lauren said his membership was canceled and he was banned from returning but she didn‚Äôt want to return either. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt want to go knowing that a bunch of the guys had seen porn of me,‚Äú she said. ‚ÄúEven though it was fake, it still made me feel really ashamed and gross.‚Äù At the advice of a loved one, Lauren turned to a lawyer who advised her she didn‚Äôt have a case for suing for defamation. Lauren said she was told she couldn‚Äôt sue under revenge porn laws because it wasn‚Äôt technically revenge porn ‚Äì it was¬†deep fake porn, which there are currently no federal laws against, as the law lags behind technological advances.\nWhile some states like Virginia and¬†California have passed laws targeting deepfake pornography, the lack of federal protection can leave victims without legal recourse. Honza Cervenka, a lawyer who specializes in nonconsensual pornography,¬†told¬†Refinery29 that for these videos and images to be considered image-based sexual abuse, the breasts or genitals of the person would have to be shown, which is often not the case in deepfake pornography. ‚ÄúIt sort of falls through the cracks of many of the laws that were written with the original revenge pornography, rather than this more sophisticated deepfake imagery,‚Äù Cervenka said.\nUldouz Wallace, an Iranian actress, was one of the stars targeted by the 2014 iCloud hack, in which private photos of celebrities including Kirsten Dunst, Jennifer Lawrence, and Kate Upton, were leaked online. Wallace, who was 25 when her private photos were hacked, watched in the ensuing years as deepfake pornography was made from her photos. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs several layers of different types of abuse,‚Äù Wallace said, ‚Äúwith the deepfake aspect of it after the whole initial hack and leak. There‚Äôs just so much [fake content] now that I don‚Äôt even know what‚Äôs what.‚Äù\nWallace is now affiliated with the¬†Sexual Violence Prevention Association (SVPA) an organization that uses ‚Äúadvocacy, education, and community engagemen‚Äùto ‚Äúcreate a world where everyone can live free from the threat of sexual violence.‚Äù In an open letter, SVPA is calling on Congress to ban deepfake porn. ‚ÄúRight now, there are no [federal] laws banning the creation or distribution of deepfake porn,‚Äù¬†the letter reads. ‚ÄúUntil there are consequences, deepfake pornography will continue to increase.‚Äù\nOmny Miranda Martone, the Founder & CEO of SVPA, said the organization is committed to helping pass federal legislation against deepfake pornography and educating people on why it‚Äôs so harmful. ‚ÄúPeople are like, well, why do [victims] even care? Joseph Morelle (D‚ÄìN.Y.).¬†‚ÄúAs artificial intelligence continues to evolve and permeate our society, it‚Äôs critical that we take proactive steps to combat the spread of disinformation and protect individuals from compromising situations online,‚Äù Morelle said. grid-layout__content"><div class="BodyWrapper-kufPGa XtZXd body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p>When Lauren* watched a video of her having sex with a man she had never been intimate with, she had a panic attack. Though the body of the woman in the video was thinner and whiter than hers, it was undeniably her face. She couldn‚Äôt stop crying. How could it look so realistic? And what could she do about it?</p><p>As the capabilities of <a href="https://www.teenvogue.com/tag/artificial-intelligence" target="_blank">artificial intelligence rapidly increase,</a> so do the ways people are targeted by it.¬†<a href="https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/love-and-sex-in-the-digital-age/202302/can-deepfake-porn-impact-your-life">According to¬†<em>Psychology Today</em></a>, ‚Äú[a 2019] study reports that 96% of deepfake victims are sexualized, and nearly all of them are women.‚Äù Lauren had found herself, as many others have, the victim of <a href="https://www.teenvogue.com/story/what-is-deepfake">deepfake</a> porn ‚Äì an¬†<a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2023/mar/13/deepfake-pornography-explosion">increasingly popular subset of pornography</a> where a person‚Äôs face is superimposed onto another person‚Äôs body and then seen engaging in sexual activity. The creators of deepfake porn don‚Äôt have to be computer geniuses ‚Äì the videos¬†<a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2023/02/13/ai-porn-deepfakes-women-consent/">can be created with relatively simple¬†face swapping¬†apps</a> available on most phones. Newer, more advanced AI tech makes the phenomenon even more likely to proliferate.¬†</p><div><div class="ConsumerMarketingUnitThemedWrapper-iUTMTf jssHut consumer-marketing-unit consumer-marketing-unit--article-mid-content" role="presentation" aria-hidden="true"><div class="consumer-marketing-unit__slot consumer-marketing-unit__slot--article-mid-content consumer-marketing-unit__slot--in-content"></div><div class="journey-unit"></div></div></div><p>Lauren, whose name has been changed for privacy concerns, was the subject of deepfake porn after Dan*, a man she met at the local gym asked her out on a date. When she told him she wasn‚Äôt interested, she didn‚Äôt think much of it but Lauren says the next time she saw Dan at the gym, the situation escalated. ‚ÄúHe became aggressive and frustrated, saying I should just give him a chance,‚Äù Lauren said. I should have told the gym management but I was embarrassed and just wanted to get out of there.‚Äù When Lauren returned to the gym again, she said a man followed her toward the locker rooms and said he needed to speak to her. ‚ÄúHe told me Dan was showing people a video of us having sex,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt believe him at first because I‚Äôd never had sex with Dan so it didn‚Äôt seem possible.‚Äù</p><div class="Container-bkChBi byNLHx"></div><p>But thanks to the rise in deepfake and face swap technology, it was possible. Dan had created a video that appeared to show him and Lauren having sex and was showing the men at the gym, Lauren said. A few days later, Dan posted the video on his Instagram story, using Lauren‚Äôs first and last name and bragging that he would turn the fake video into a reality. After reporting Dan to the management of the gym, Lauren said his membership was canceled and he was banned from returning but she didn‚Äôt want to return either. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt want to go knowing that a bunch of the guys had seen porn of me,‚Äú she said. ‚ÄúEven though it was fake, it still made me feel really ashamed and gross.‚Äù At the advice of a loved one, Lauren turned to a lawyer who advised her she didn‚Äôt have a case for suing for defamation. Lauren said she was told she couldn‚Äôt sue under revenge porn laws because it wasn‚Äôt technically revenge porn ‚Äì it was¬†<a href="https://www.refinery29.com/en-us/2023/02/11283094/deepfake-porn-laws-atrioc#:~:text=But%20despite%20some%20states%20taking,not%20be%20illegal%20in%20another.">deep fake porn, which there are currently no federal laws against</a>, as the law lags behind technological advances.</p></div></div></div><div class="GridItem-buujkM fVLMby grid--item grid-layout__aside"><div class="body__inner-container"><p>While <a href="https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-48839758">some states like Virginia</a> and¬†<a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2019/oct/07/california-makes-deepfake-videos-illegal-but-law-may-be-hard-to-enforce">California</a> have passed laws targeting deepfake pornography, the lack of federal protection can leave victims without legal recourse. Honza Cervenka, a lawyer who specializes in nonconsensual pornography,¬†<a href="https://www.refinery29.com/en-us/2023/02/11283094/deepfake-porn-laws-atrioc#:~:text=But%20despite%20some%20states%20taking,not%20be%20illegal%20in%20another.">told¬†<em>Refinery29</em></a> that for these videos and images to be considered image-based sexual abuse, the breasts or genitals of the person would have to be shown, which is often not the case in deepfake pornography. ‚ÄúIt sort of falls through the cracks of many of the laws that were written with the original revenge pornography, rather than this more sophisticated deepfake imagery,‚Äù Cervenka said.¬†</p><div class="AdWrapper-dQtivb fZrssQ ad ad--in-content"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--in-content" data-node-id="ypnmx"></div></div><p>Uldouz Wallace, an Iranian actress, was one of the stars <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2018/08/29/entertainment/celebrity-photo-hacking-sentence/index.html">targeted by the 2014 iCloud hack</a>, in which private photos of celebrities including Kirsten Dunst, Jennifer Lawrence, and Kate Upton, were leaked online. Wallace, who was 25 when her private photos were hacked, watched in the ensuing years as deepfake pornography was made from her photos. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs several layers of different types of abuse,‚Äù Wallace said, ‚Äúwith the deepfake aspect of it after the whole initial hack and leak. There‚Äôs just so much [fake content] now that I don‚Äôt even know what‚Äôs what.‚Äù</p><p>Wallace is now affiliated with the¬†<a data-offer-url="https://s-v-p-a.org/about-us/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://s-v-p-a.org/about-us/"}" href="https://s-v-p-a.org/about-us/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">Sexual Violence Prevention Association</a> (SVPA) an organization that uses ‚Äúadvocacy, education, and community engagemen‚Äùto ‚Äúcreate a world where everyone can live free from the threat of sexual violence.‚Äù In an open letter, SVPA is calling on Congress to ban deepfake porn. ‚ÄúRight now, there are no [federal] laws banning the creation or distribution of deepfake porn,‚Äù¬†<a data-offer-url="https://s-v-p-a.org/bandeepfakeporn/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://s-v-p-a.org/bandeepfakeporn/"}" href="https://s-v-p-a.org/bandeepfakeporn/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">the letter reads</a>. ‚ÄúUntil there are consequences, deepfake pornography will continue to increase.‚Äù¬†</p><p>Omny Miranda Martone, the Founder & CEO of SVPA, said the organization is committed to helping pass federal legislation against deepfake pornography and educating people on why it‚Äôs so harmful. ‚ÄúPeople are like, well, why do [victims] even care? It‚Äôs not real anyways. It‚Äôs not actually them,‚Äù Martone said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think a lot of people fully understand the consent piece of this ‚Äì that you don‚Äôt have the person‚Äôs consent and this is a violation of autonomy and privacy.‚Äù</p><p>As the use of artificial intelligence and deepfake technology becomes even more common ‚Äì there is an increasing need for standards for protection to be set through bills like the¬†<a href="https://thehill.com/homenews/house/3990659-ny-democrat-unveils-bill-to-criminalize-sharing-deepfake-porn/#:~:text=The%20bill%2C%20titled%20the%20%E2%80%9CPreventing,their%20anonymity%20in%20the%20cases.">Preventing Deepfakes of¬†Intimate Images Act</a> which was introduced by Rep. Joseph Morelle (D‚ÄìN.Y.).¬†‚ÄúAs artificial intelligence continues to evolve and permeate our society, it‚Äôs critical that we take proactive steps to combat the spread of disinformation and protect individuals from compromising situations online,‚Äù Morelle said. As of publication, the bill has not advanced through the House of Representatives.</p><p><strong>Let us slide into your DMs.</strong> <a readabilityObject.title: Deepfake Porn Victims Are Seeking Federal Protections Through Legislation
readabilityObject.content:
When Lauren* watched a video of her having sex with a man she had never been intimate with, she had a panic attack. Though the body of the woman in the video was thinner and whiter than hers, it was undeniably her face. She couldn‚Äôt stop crying. How could it look so realistic? And what could she do about it?

As the capabilities of artificial intelligence rapidly increase, so do the ways people are targeted by it. According to Psychology Today, ‚Äú[a 2019] study reports that 96% of deepfake victims are sexualized, and nearly all of them are women.‚Äù Lauren had found herself, as many others have, the victim of deepfake porn ‚Äì an increasingly popular subset of pornography where a person‚Äôs face is superimposed onto another person‚Äôs body and then seen engaging in sexual activity. The creators of deepfake porn don‚Äôt have to be computer geniuses ‚Äì the videos can be created with relatively simple face swapping apps available on most phones. Newer, more advanced AI tech makes the phenomenon even more likely to proliferate. 

Lauren, whose name has been changed for privacy concerns, was the subject of deepfake porn after Dan*, a man she met at the local gym asked her out on a date. When she told him she wasn‚Äôt interested, she didn‚Äôt think much of it but Lauren says the next time she saw Dan at the gym, the situation escalated. ‚ÄúHe became aggressive and frustrated, saying I should just give him a chance,‚Äù Lauren said. I should have told the gym management but I was embarrassed and just wanted to get out of there.‚Äù When Lauren returned to the gym again, she said a man followed her toward the locker rooms and said he needed to speak to her. ‚ÄúHe told me Dan was showing people a video of us having sex,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt believe him at first because I‚Äôd never had sex with Dan so it didn‚Äôt seem possible.‚Äù

But thanks to the rise in deepfake and face swap technology, it was possible. Dan had created a video that appeared to show him and Lauren having sex and was showing the men at the gym, Lauren said. A few days later, Dan posted the video on his Instagram story, using Lauren‚Äôs first and last name and bragging that he would turn the fake video into a reality. After reporting Dan to the management of the gym, Lauren said his membership was canceled and he was banned from returning but she didn‚Äôt want to return either. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt want to go knowing that a bunch of the guys had seen porn of me,‚Äú she said. ‚ÄúEven though it was fake, it still made me feel really ashamed and gross.‚Äù At the advice of a loved one, Lauren turned to a lawyer who advised her she didn‚Äôt have a case for suing for defamation. Lauren said she was told she couldn‚Äôt sue under revenge porn laws because it wasn‚Äôt technically revenge porn ‚Äì it was deep fake porn, which there are currently no federal laws against, as the law lags behind technological advances.

While some states like Virginia and California have passed laws targeting deepfake pornography, the lack of federal protection can leave victims without legal recourse. Honza Cervenka, a lawyer who specializes in nonconsensual pornography, told Refinery29 that for these videos and images to be considered image-based sexual abuse, the breasts or genitals of the person would have to be shown, which is often not the case in deepfake pornography. ‚ÄúIt sort of falls through the cracks of many of the laws that were written with the original revenge pornography, rather than this more sophisticated deepfake imagery,‚Äù Cervenka said. 

Uldouz Wallace, an Iranian actress, was one of the stars targeted by the 2014 iCloud hack, in which private photos of celebrities including Kirsten Dunst, Jennifer Lawrence, and Kate Upton, were leaked online. Wallace, who was 25 when her private photos were hacked, watched in the ensuing years as deepfake pornography was made from her photos. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs several layers of different types of abuse,‚Äù Wallace said, ‚Äúwith the deepfake aspect of it after the whole initial hack and leak. There‚Äôs just so much [fake content] now that I don‚Äôt even know what‚Äôs what.‚Äù

Wallace is now affiliated with the Sexual Violence Prevention Association (SVPA) an organization that uses ‚Äúadvocacy, education, and community engagemen‚Äùto ‚Äúcreate a world where everyone can live free from the threat of sexual violence.‚Äù In an open letter, SVPA is calling on Congress to ban deepfake porn. ‚ÄúRight now, there are no [federal] laws banning the creation or distribution of deepfake porn,‚Äù the letter reads. ‚ÄúUntil there are consequences, deepfake pornography will continue to increase.‚Äù 

Omny Miranda Martone, the Founder & CEO of SVPA, said the organization is committed to helping pass federal legislation against deepfake pornography and educating people on why it‚Äôs so harmful. ‚ÄúPeople are like, well, why do [victims] even care? It‚Äôs not real anyways. It‚Äôs not actually them,‚Äù Martone said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think a lot of people fully understand the consent piece of this ‚Äì that you don‚Äôt have the person‚Äôs consent and this is a violation of autonomy and privacy.‚Äù

As the use of artificial intelligence and deepfake technology becomes even more common ‚Äì there is an increasing need for standards for protection to be set through bills like the Preventing Deepfakes of Intimate Images Act which was introduced by Rep. Joseph Morelle (D‚ÄìN.Y.). ‚ÄúAs artificial intelligence continues to evolve and permeate our society, it‚Äôs critical that we take proactive steps to combat the spread of disinformation and protect individuals from compromising situations online,‚Äù Morelle said. As of publication, the bill has not advanced through the House of Representatives.
